description: Unknown; many unproven stories exist. The word first appeared in 1806 (see citation below).

adjectives.description: cocktail (comparative more cocktail, superlative most cocktail)

examples: The cocktail in Britain is a rigidly-defined social institution: each has its own particular meaningâ€”the G & T is the alcoholic equivalent of the interview suit; Pernod and black is an alternative to glue sniffing for repentant trendies, etc.

entries.meaning: (by extension) A mixture of other substances or things.
examples: Scientists found a cocktail of pollutants in the river downstream from the chemical factory.

entries.meaning: A horse, not of pure breed, but having only one eighth or one sixteenth impure blood in its veins.
(UK, slang, dated) A mean, half-hearted fellow.
A species of rove beetle, so called from its habit of elevating the tail.

verbs.description: cocktail (third-person singular simple present cocktails, present participle cocktailing, simple past and past participle cocktailed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To adulterate (fuel, etc.) by mixing in other substances.

examples: He dined and cocktailed her at the most exclusive bars and restaurants.
